author: Alexandra Scaggs
title: Treasuries Pare Gains as Unemployment Rate Drops in August
text:
Treasuries pared gains as the unemployment rate fell in August even while the U.S. added fewer jobs than forecast, as traders ponder whether the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates when it meets this month.
Yields on U.S. government debt climbed from earlier lows after a Labor Department report showed 173,000 jobs were created in August, fewer than the 217,000 median forecast from economists in a Bloomberg survey. Average hourly earnings climbed more than forecast and workers put in a longer workweek, the report also showed.
“I was on the fence for September, but now I’m much more confident they would hike in October,” said Brian Jacobsen, chief portfolio strategist for Wells Fargo Advantage Funds in Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin. “It’s a pretty disappointing number.”
Benchmark 10-year Treasury note yields fell 1 basis point, or 0.01 percentage point, to 2.15 percent as of 8:50 a.m. in New York, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader prices.
The gain in payrolls followed advances in July and June that were stronger than previously reported, the Labor Department said Friday. The unemployment rate fell to the lowest since April 2008.
Futures prices indicated traders saw a 32 percent chance of a rate increase when the Fed meets Sept. 16-17, according to data compiled by Bloomberg, based on the assumption that the benchmark will average 0.375 percent after liftoff. That’s up from 26 percent earlier Friday but down from a 38 percent probability at the end of last week.

author: Klaus Wille
title: Quantedge Hedge Fund Lost 16% in August From Market Turmoil
text:
Quantedge Global Fund, Asia’s second-best performing macro hedge fund last year, tumbled 16.1 percent in August, as market turmoil across equities, currencies and commodities caused computer-driven trading strategies to unravel.
The decline brings the quantitative macro hedge fund’s year-to-date loss to 16 percent, according to a person with knowledge of the matter who requested anonymity. Assets under management were at $992 million as of the end of August, the person said. Quantedge, which started with $3 million in October 2006, increased its assets under management to $1.05 billion at the end of December. Meeshell Koh, a spokesperson for Quantedge, did not immediately have comment on the returns.
Quantedge, managed by Singapore-based Quantedge Capital Pte, joins other hedge funds relying on computer models that posted losses last month as global markets were rattled by concerns that China’s economy is slowing. Winton Capital Management lost an estimated 4.3 percent in August in its $11.8 billion Winton Futures Fund, the worst month since July 2008, according to a letter sent to investors last week. Cantab Capital Partners erased gains for the year in its $2.6 billion CCP Quantitative strategy after it slumped 10 percent, an investor letter last week showed.
The Eurekahedge Global Macro Hedge Fund Index lost 0.8 percent in August, according to the Singapore-based data provider. The index has gained 0.9 percent since the beginning of the year, on track for the lowest return in four years.
Markets Plunge The MSCI World Index plummeted 6.8 percent in August, the most in more than three years, while emerging market currencies fell and the Bloomberg USD Emerging Market Corporate Bond Index declined 2 percent, the most in eight months.
Quantedge Global Fund was founded by former reinsurance pricing actuary Leow Kah Shin and Chua Choong Tze, who had previously taught a course in portfolio management at Singapore Management University.
The fund gained 29.4 percent in 2014, and returned an annualized 30 percent between its inception in October 2006 and the end of December, according to data from Eurekahedge Pte.

author: Reuters
title: CANADA STOCKS-TSX jumps at open as miners cheer rising copper prices
text:
TORONTO, Sept 8 Canada's main stock index jumped at the open on Tuesday, with a surge in copper prices and other commodities boosting the mining sector and financial stocks also making healthy gains.
The Toronto Stock Exchange's S&P/TSX composite index was up 157.81 points, or 1.17 percent, to 13,636.12. All 10 main groups were higher. (Reporting by Alastair Sharp )

title: BRIEF-Edifier Technology signs agreement with Alibaba's unit on intelligence cloud service

author: Reuters
title: UPDATE 1-Pentair to appoint Trian's Ed Garden to board
text:
(Adds details, background)
Sept 8 (Reuters) - Pump and valve maker Pentair Plc said it would appoint Ed Garden, founding partner of hedge fund Trian Fund Management LP, to its board.
The appointment of Garden, who is also on the board of Wendys Co and Bank of New York Mellon Corp, will increase the size of Pentair's board to 12.
Trian, which is led by activist investor Nelson Peltz, disclosed a 7.24 percent stake in Pentair in June, making it the second-largest shareholder of the company.
Trian had asked the company in June to bulk up through deals in the fragmented industry.
Pentair's revenue fell 9.4 percent in the second quarter ended June 27, hurt by stronger dollar and slower growth in oil and gas industry shipments.
Over the past couple of years, Peltz has targeted DuPont and PepsiCo Inc among others, demanding board seats and asking them to separate their fast-growing businesses from the ones where growth had stagnated.
Up to Friday's close, Pentair's stock had fallen about 20 percent to $53.19 on the Nasdaq this year. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Saumyadeb Chakrabarty)

author: Reuters
title: Japan's Nikkei share average falls below 17,450.77, wiping out year-to-date gains
text:
Sept 8 Japan's Nikkei share average fell below 17,450.77 on Tuesday, wiping out year-to-date gains.
The benchmark Japanese index lost 2.5 percent to 17,416.12 and remained volatile in late afternoon trading. (Reporting by Joshua Hunt; Editing by Chang-Ran Kim )

title: China In Trade Slump As Imports Dive 13.8%
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Sep 8, 2015, 11:29 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 1 mins China In Trade Slump As Imports Dive 13.8% By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 1 hour 53 minutes ago View Photo 

The extent of the dive in domestic demand in China has been laid bare, with official figures showing a 13.8% slump in imports last month compared to a year earlier. 
The trade statistics - which are being followed more closely amid recent market turmoil over the state of the world's second largest economy - also show exports fell by 6.2%. 
The figures marked the 10th consecutive month of falling imports, with the devaluation of the yuan last month by the Chinese authorities denting the prospect of an improvement in the coming months. 
Much of China's imports are commodities and other raw materials going into factories that turn them into goods for sale overseas, so the fall could be an ominous sign for exports in the coming months. 
Stock markets in Asia were fairly resilient after the release of the gloomy trade figures, though the Nikkei in Japan fell 2.4% following official figures showing its economy contracted at an annual rate of 1.2% between April and June. 
The Shanghai Composite, which has lost around 40% of its value since mid-June, recovered from early falls following the release of the Chinese trade figures to post a gain of 2.9% by the close. 
The Beijing authorities have used a series of interventions to try and shore up the stock market, ranging from state purchases to removing income tax from dividends on shares held for more than a year. 
The trade data adds further pressure on China's communist leaders to keep the economy from slowing too fast and shedding too many jobs. 
Policymakers have cut interest rates five times since November in a bid to shore up economic growth.
